comments.commentBody: The IG report creates a false and retroactive standard and applies it to past facts. The rules were murky when the Secretary began using her private email address for State Department work, did so for years and never tried to hide the fact, was never told to stop by anyone, and was never required to turn over the thousands of government emails she, in fact, preserved after her departure until requested to do so because of litigation. Sounds like the folks who are really at fault are those who run IT and records management at the State Department, not to mention its legal advisors. But the IG goes after the Senator? Oh, and her server was apparently never hacked, unlike the numerous times the federal government's servers have been. I do agree, however, that the Secretary needs a better game plan to deal with Donald Trump's endless attacks using this non issue against her.

And the chorus goes on and on. We are told again and again how competent Mrs. Clinton is, by her supporters, by the New York Times, and to question her qualifications makes you a Bernie Bro.  What makes her willful blindness so painful to watch is the realization that she'll be the other option to the Donald and her hubris may well bring her and us down with her.  This is the stuff of Greek Tragedy.  If she really cared about the country she would drop out.
To quote Bernie Sanders: "enough with the damn emails". It Doesn't matter, just a strategy to discourage democrats from voting.

Let me get this straight.
For a presidential candidate the republicans have given us a fact-adverse, anti-woman, anti-planned parenthood, anti-abortion, anti-voting rights, anti- LBGT rights, anti-Department Of Education, anti-science, anti-Mexican, anti-EPA, anti-diplomacy, anti-trade, anti-gun control, anti-yada-yada billionaire narcissist who in other times wouldn’t be elected dog catcher, and we’re supposed to be upset because Secretary Clinton may have misused an email server and is now “drowning”?
Yeah…right. Next.

She just displays so much bad judgment.  I once swore (in a letter to her about her Iraq vote) that I would not vote for her again, although I voted for her to be senator. I think Trump is going to be the next president, and I don't want to have any of the responsibility for that fiasco. So I may have to just vote against him, but I will never vote for her. She just has bad judgment.

A little perspective would be helpful. Ms. Clinton never claimed to be an expert in IT security, and there is no reason, even in hindsight, to expect her to be one. She wanted to read her unclassified e-mail on her Blackberry. Her staff and the State Department developed a solution that, in hindsight was unsatisfactory. Beyond the convenience of using a device she was familiar with she gained no advantage, no status, no money, no sex (which is, I suppose, why others wouldn't do such a thing). National security was not seriously harmed, if it was harmed at all. If she seems somewhat defensive look at the hyperventilated response of the Republicans and the media. Let's move on to more important things.

The report does not hold up to scrutiny.

1) The Secretary of State is a cabinet member and answers directly to the President. It is not an elected position and it is not an appointment usually given to State Department employees or insiders. The Secretary is not an employee of the Department of State. She is direct member of the Executive. If there was any irregularity in Mrs. Clinton's KNOWN correspondence methods, then only President Obama would give or deny "clearance." He made no move, so there is no issue of "clearance."

2) Mrs. Clinton had valid reasons to worry about the security of her correspondence. The private server seems to have protected these documents effectively. Using it appears to have been a wise move.

3) Despite the innuendo of the report, the facts show that there was NO standard e-mail practice established for Secretaries of State. In the absence of a known standard, there is no reasonable assumption that Mrs. Clinton would "know" her practices were non-standard. In fact, it seems she simply continued her own established security practices, and was never challenged on them.

5) The report comes far, far, far, far, FAR too late to make any difference at all to the actual issues discussed in the e-mails. It has no practical relevance and is nothing but a political hit.

@Jolan: Absolutely correct, lost in all the theatricality and atmospherics, and the heart of the matter: The State Department was well aware that Clinton was using a private server and did not instruct her to shut it down. Why would she not have believed that, despite the fact that the state department was not thrilled that she was using a private server, it was tacitly permitting her to do so? In fact, it was tacitly permitting her to do so.

I am supporting Sanders until he drops out and will support Clinton if she is the nominee, which she almost certainly will be. Nobody is looking at the facts here and nobody is really reading the report. The conclusions do not match the fact-finding. They knew she was using it, and she was not told to shut it down. That is the point.

In her arrogance & dishonesty in this matter, she's a cross between Dick Cheney and Nixon.

Listening to Hillary surrogates spend 24 hours answering questions madly spinning "She did nothing wrong/it's not important/she followed the rules at the time/Colin Powell/but DONALD TRUMP DONALD TRUMP DONALD TRUMP"

As if Trump's awfulness is why she deserves a pass on this - violating national security procedures, ignoring the State Dept's warnings about using private email, not telling State her server may have been hacked, lying repeatedly to the authorities & the public, refusing to cooperate with the State investigation as every other recent Secretary of State cooperated, & finally today saying "Nothing has changed."

Watching Donna Brazille, Claire McCaskill, Joel Benenson & others tying themselves in knots trying to paint this as inconsequential or 'just misogyny' reminded me of the public figures who propped up Nixon in 1974.

I feel such disgust. i actually believed she was better than this.

She's not.

This is her Watergate.

Red flag. She's unqualified to be president.

Anyone who can ignore official government policy for national security as stipulated by her employer because it's personally 'convenient' to ignore it, lie about it & cover it up should never be president.

Mark Halperin pointed out that after this if she was nominated to be Attorney General she couldn't get confirmed.

Appalling.

Finally, the NYT acknowledges that there is a reason for the widespread distrust.  Candor is not a weapon in Hillary's arsenal.  She just assumes that people will believe the talking points her campaign puts out or that it will be enough to say, however awful she is, Donald Trump is worse. For me, both are horrible.  Neither should be President.

When I was in the service a Lieutenant left a secret document in his locked desk drawer rather than an approved safe and was subsequently punished and relieved. Another Lieutenant wrote an unclassified plan that had classified information inserted. He was also punished and relieved.

That Clinton, with her extensive experience in the government could mishandle dozens of documents with classified material, marked or unmarked, without the common sense to protect it accordingly is mind-boggling. That she could escape judgement for such a lengthy period points to collusion in multiple government agencies including the executive and FBI. It doesn't take months to determine that someone mishandled classified information. FBI get off your duff. Charge her and let the trial begin.

Ask the two young Lieutenants if Hillary should get a pass!

You are absolutely correct in recommending that Sec. Clinton address the email controversy "with a far greater investment of candor before the public" than she has shown before, or even now in trying to avoid and obfuscate by saying Colin Powell did it (when, in fact, his server was in his office where he was promoting change in the State Department's lagging technology and he used the government system most of the time).  I'm a progressive Democratic who desperately would like to feel comfortable supporting Sec. Clinton, but I, like so many others, feel that she's not only hiding something, especially when she and her top aides refused to be interviewed by the Inspector General, and therefore I cannot trust her, but also I feel that her judgment is lacking despite her years of government service.  This is an issue that both Donald Trump and his Republican allies in the House of Representatives will not let go of until and unless Sec. Clinton faces it head on with the openness and forthrightness that has been lacking so far. Mrs. Clinton has to realize that she has to win our trust in order to win our support.

I agree Hillary needlessly hunkers down too quickly. She does this because of her experience as the target of partisan attacks. The editorial makes a good case for forthrightness and transparency especially when mistakes are made. Nevertheless, all the partisan hyperbole in the world can't turn a violation of the Federal Records Act, since rectified, into a national security scandal. The best critics can say it was a potential national security breach. As a practical matter would using the State Dept. server and email address have protected her emails from hackers? I doubt it. Maybe we should focus on that part of the equation too.

"Trustworthiness" and in a nutshell that is the major problem for Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Can the American Public actually trust what she stands for and what she is just saying to get there?

Democrats have a choice to make either give the election to the Republicans on a silver platter by nominating Hillary Clinton as their candidate or have a Democrat in the White house who is Bernie Sanders. Choice is theirs to make.

In the general election Trump would eat Hillary alive and won't even burp. Just remember what he did to all his republican buddies.

It is still possible for the Justice department to do the right thing and indict her and save the Democrats the awkward decision that they would need to make to ensure that America does not elect Donald Trump as the President.

Hillary's 'trustworthiness' amounts to an issue of professional convenience (due to an antiquated and certainly insecure network at State in 2010) and/or personal convenience (due to the nature of an antiquated yet very functional and well-funded political vendetta following her out of Arkansas since the late-80s).

It was noted last week, along with Ken Starr, that some conservatives, after 9-11, regretted that they preoccupied the Clinton WH with scores of legal harrassments (before catching a break with Monica Lewinsky) that may have allowed the terror attacks to go unnoticed as they were being planned. Since no one actually believes Hillary is on some foreign payroll to undermine her own country, those who consider her 'untrustworthy' would do well to ask themselves what the NATURE of her untrustworthiness is...or could it simply be a matter of self-protection within a manufactured and neverending smear campaign that has followed her every day of her professional life?

Those who say "it doesn't matter" have generated an equal amount of dismissiveness for their cause. There are only so many times "Wolf!" can be called before it becomes just so much noise.

Recipe for a Clinton investigation: Pick a topic at random. Brain storm vague but Serious Questions. Hyperventilate about the lack of detailed specific "answers" in the days since the questions were asked. Receive monstrously detailed answers for 98% of the questions. Ask what she's "hiding" in the remaining two percent. Conduct detailed official investigations for years, cross examining every one she has ever known or spoken to or been friends of friends of Facebook friends with. Release report admitting that nothing serious has been found. Wonder what she is still hiding. Marvel at what a successful crook she is, to get through all of the investigations without ever finding any evidence that would pass the laugh test in a court. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat. Find someone else to repeat it again.

Yes, these emails are now a legitimate issue because of Mrs. Clinton's clumsy attempt to evade responsibility for putting their security at risk.  But let's not forget that her system was not breached and she did not use a private server for any nefarious purpose.  While Mrs. Clinton might now have an email problem, Bernie Sanders has an experience and effectiveness problem, and Donald Trump is a total embarrassment who lacks the gravitas to run for local school board.  While Mrs. Clinton will have to dig herself out of this email controversy, she still stands head and shoulders above her opponents in terms of presidential qualities.  As the Times said in endorsing her, she is perhaps the best qualified person to become president in recent American history.  The stakes are too high to lose sight of the big picture.

Thanks, NYTimes, for piling on.

More fuel for the Trump fires. Do you WANT Trump to win this election?

This email kerfuffle is minor compared to the stupidity that is the Trump campaign. How does he even compare to someone with Clinton's experience and knowledge?

--Birther
--Climate denier
--Quotes the "National Enquirer" for crying out loud!
--Won't release his taxes. What is he hiding??
--Name caller and making juvenile insults
--Has to get a list of Court nominees from the Heritage Foundation. When are you going to ask him why he wants Judge Don Willett, who has openly made fun of him on Twitter.

How about pushing harder at the guy who has NO BUSINESS in the White House?

This is an absurd non-issue.  So she had a private account and server.  It was against the rules.  What are we worried that she was doing?  Embezzling tax-payer dollars?  Trying to undermine her Republican opponent?  Murdering her friend?  Here is a 60-something career politician being raked over the coals for, uh ... well clearly she had the technology sophistication to manipulate ... uh ... what?  Have a little more control over who sees her emails?  Ah, but it compromised national security ... Because, uh ... she didn't care about national security?  Or wait, yeah - maybe she wanted to kill some of our diplomats in Benghazi ... ?  C'mon people, get a life.  This is nothing.  Nothing.  NOTHING.  I know lots of people who had their own server at that time because ... it was cool.  Because you could.  God help our country.  And please, people of the press, please get real and cover something that matters.
Where are you now when we need you Joe Biden?

I'm not happy that Mrs. Clinton chose to use a private server for her email communications. However, in context...

At the time this choice was made, early 2009, Mrs. Clinton had just spent many weeks campaigning energetically for Obama, and before she could take a breath, she accepted Obama's request to become SoS, with its intensive travel requirements, and off she went. (Quite a bit of repair work to do on behalf of our country, which apparently she succeeded at.)

So she continued to use her existing email server, which she had used as a Senator, and her husband had used as a former President, apparently without any security problems for either of them, and which she knew worked well - as opposed to the State Department's archaic technology.

Apparently, she broke no laws in doing so. It was not illegal to do so. And it looks like there were no significant security breaches linked to her email use. (I think we would have heard from the FBI by this time if there were.)

Did Mrs. Clinton represent the interests of the United States competently and helpfully as Secretary of State? Most people thought so, if polls taken at the time of her service were accurate.

Why, then, is her use of a private email server now seen as the defining characteristic of her service as SoS, when it did not have any negative consequences?

I trust her. She has been working without cease on progressive causes for three decades. I trust that she will continue to do so as President.

Hillary Clinton basically told her staff to do two things: a) make it so that she only needed to carry around just one communications device for both work and personal use; b) make sure her personal messages could be kept separately and not be subject to information requests. I would challenge anyone to name one federal government official that doesn't wish to keep their personal messages private. They do have a legal right to do so, just like the rest of us. A thousand corporate executives a day order their IT staffs to do the very same thing. Corporate employees often need to carry two devices, while executives are frequently rendered exempt by their own decree. She asked, her staff simply executed.  Who would question the head of the State Department in any administration? That said, it was a mistake for her to do it. She admitted that long ago. What it was not, is illegal. No grand conspiracy is in play. There are hundreds of thousands of private servers in homes across the country. They are not exotic nor mysterious. The press sometimes makes it sound like some kind of sinister laboratory operating in the Clinton basement. Until this story arose, many other nameless politicians were also likely using private email. Some probably own servers. They certainly won't admit to that now. An administrative mistake was made in a town famous for it's billion dollar boondoggles. Overblown does not even begin to describe this non-scandal of most grandiose proportions.

What is lost in the politics surrounding this report are the facts that:

a) State Department people knew she was using a private email server and did not send her a directive to stop -- if they even have that authority. This could constitute allowing her to do so.

b) Numerous emails reveal that she and her aids were aware of the rules regarding what they could and could not communicate about over her private email and avoided emailing on those sensitive subjects.

c) Clinton has turned over tens of thousands of emails and to date only 22 have been classified as top secret and those after the fact. They were not top secret at the time they were sent.

However, Mrs. Clinton's use of the private server was bad judgement (bad judgement shared by at least one other Secretary of State who is not running for President and therefore not under investigation).

I agree with the times. She should hold a press conference to specifically address this issue. Make it clear that she made a mistake. Say she was wrong. Emphasize that there was no security breach and that no information that was shared through her private server was deemed top secret at the time. And then, answer every question about the email situation directly -- I was wrong, no security breaches, turned over emails, nothing top secret at the time.

I am a long time Republican who probably can find common ground with some long time Democrats right about now.  I simply cannot stomach pulling the lever for the person who is my party's presumptive nominee, however when I look to the other party for an option the choice is just as unconscionable ( I am hoping for a miracle and that we would at least have Bernie as a choice to consider, but that does not seem likely).  Unfortunately most of the common sense in both parties has disappeared, or else one of the two parties would have realized months ago that if we just come up with a competent candidate who does not have all of this baggage it will be a simple stroll to 1600 Pennsylvania Ave. along with probably assisting the House and Senate candidates of your party.   I think the blame can equally be placed with the "Party Leadership" on both sides, and the primary voters who for some unexplainable reason have been willing to overlook the serious faults, terrible ideas, bad decisions, dishonesty, and possible crimes of Mr. Trump and Secretary Clinton.  In America we should all expect and demand better than we are being presented with.

I am a life-long Democrat and am astounded that yet again we are on some kind of zombie death-march toward picking a deeply flawed candidate. The NYT is complicit in this we-have-no-other-choice attitude, as well as the Hillary supporters who think this email thing is no big deal. All elections are irrational on some level, however, this cycle has proven that experience, money, family connections and all the old standards are out the window. If people think a majority of the electorate will elect Clinton based on her experience they are mistaken. There has been a 30-40 year process where the average citizen has been squeezed to the breaking point. They are feed up with the status quo and are now in an irrational frame of mind and we have to pay attention to this. Trump is already ahead in some national polls, and these were taken before the new email revaluations. We still have a primary going on and important ideas are still being debated. There is still a convention in front of us. We should really consider this kind death-march mentality.
